Others: The Kansas City Royals completed one of the most remarkable turnarounds in major league history, clinching an AL wild card despite a 3-0 loss to the Atlanta Braves.
A year ago, the Royals matched a franchise record with 106 losses. Now, they are headed to the postseason for the first time since winning the 2015 World Series.
The Royals are the first team in baseball history to make the playoffs after posting such a dismal mark the previous season.
Since the start of the expansion era in 1961, the Royals are just the third team to advance to the postseason after losing at least 100 games the previous year.

General manager J.J. Piccolo didn’t break the bank to build a winner, with players either on the team last year and just needing time to grow, or free-agent signings and trade acquisitions that underscored his baseball savvy.
Seth Lugo, Michael Wacha, Cole Ragans, Brady Singer, and Michael Lorenzen have contributed significantly to the rotation.
Lucas Erceg earned 11 saves since the Royals landed him in a trade with Milwaukee.
Bobby Witt Jr. became the first shortstop in major league history with multiple seasons of at least 30 homers and 30 steals.
Witt tops the majors with 210 hits and a.332 average, to go along with 32 homers, 109 RBIs and 31 stolen bases.
Veteran catcher Salvador Perez also is having a huge offensive season with 27 homers and 104 RBIs.

Fans in Kansas City have seen Witt’s stardom blossoming for several seasons, culminating in a Home Run Derby final appearance.
Witt can now look forward to an even bigger stage: the postseason.
